topic.title: Data Protect Information Processing

li.p:
The ingress data processing subsystem contains two cascaded protection information (PI) processing engines PI1 and PI2. Each engine performs an identical function but is configured independently in the inbound message request.
The protection information field, is always located in the last 8 bytes of a block.
Both PI1 and PI2 engines support the three types of protection information formats. The format for each protection information is shown as in the following figure: Formats for Protection Information
NVMe data protection information provides T10 DIF- or DIX-like protection.
The guard field contains a CRC16 computed over the contents of the corresponding block data. The CRC16 uses the generator polynomial G(x) = 0x18BB7. See ISO/IEC 14776-323, and SCSI Block Commands (SBC-3) [T10/1799-D] for details regarding CRC16 computation.
The application tag contains application specific data.
The reference tag identifies the address of the sector and is used to ensure that the correct sector is transferred.
Extended Protection Information
The guard field contains a CRC32 computed over the contents of the corresponding block data. The CRC32 uses CRC-32C (Castagnoli) with generator polynomial G(x) = 0x1EDC6F41.
The reference tag identifies the address of the block and is used to ensure that the correct block is transferred.
CRC64 Protection Information
The guard field contains a CRC64 computed over the contents of the corresponding sector data. The CRC64 uses CRC64-ECMA-182 with generator polynomial G(x) = 0x42F0E1EBA9EA3693.
Protection information type is configured per inbound message request in the field of PI1PIMode and P2PIMode for PI1 and PI2 engines, respectively.
The protection information processing supports three operation modes: check and forward, check and strip, and insert as shown in the following figure. The operation mode is set per inbound message request. PI Operation Modes
When the operation mode is set to check and forward mode, the PI gets checked and then forwarded to output data stream. The PI operation mode is set to this mode by setting inbound message field PI1OpMode or PI2OpMode to ChkFwd. There is no block size change as a result of check and forward operation. The protection information can be enabled or disabled individually for each field by the inbound message field PI1GardEn, P1AppTagEn, and P1RefTagEn for PI1 engine, or PI2GardEn, P2AppTagEn, and P2RefTagEn for PI2 engine, respectively. If enabled, the corresponding PI field in the input data block is checked against locally computed value, if there is a mismatch, a PI error is detected.
When the operation mode is set to check and strip mode, the PI gets checked and then stripped out from the input block. The PI operation mode is set to this mode by setting the inbound message field PI1OpMode or PI2OpMode to ChkStrip. The output block size is reduced by 8 Bytes as a result of check and strip.
When the operation mode is set to insert mode, the locally computed PI field is inserted at end of each block. The PI operation mode is set to this mode by setting inbound message field PI1OpMode or PI2OpMode to Insert. The output block size is increased by 8 Bytes as a result of check and insert.
The PI field values used for PI check and insertion operation are computed using the input data block and the parameters from the inbound message.
CRC value is computed over the user data per input block. The initial CRC seed for CRC generation can be selected either from register PI1DefaultSeed and PI2DefaultSeed or from message field PI1CRCSeed and PI2CRCSeed. The CRC seed is selected by PI1CRCSeedSel or PI2CRCSeedSel in the message. The CRC seed is either constant across all input blocks for the current request, or incremental per input block set by PI1SeedMode and PI2SeedMode in the request message. The CRC generated is optionally inverted before being used for check or insertion by setting message field PI1CRCInv to 1.
The application tag is always constant across all input blocks for the current request, and is set to message field P1PIAppTag or P2PIAppTag. The PI operation mode is set to check and forward or check and strip, the application tag check is masked bit wise by PI1AppTagMask or PI2AppTagMask bit vectors provided by inbound message request.
The reference tag is either constant across all input blocks for the current request, or incremented per input block. The value in constant mode or in incremental mode, which is the reference tag value for the first block for the current request, is set to inbound message field PI1RefTagInit or PI2RefTagInit.
PI checking may be disabled as a side effect of the content of the protection information field in a block from input data stream. The PI Check Disable Mode (P1ChkDisableMode or PI2ChkDiableMode) field in the message request controls the disabling of the protection information.
When the PI1ChkDisableMode or PI2ChkDisableMode field is set to Never, then enabled protection information checking is never disabled as a side effect of the contents of the protection information fields.
When the PI1ChkDisableMode or PI2ChkDisableMode field is set to AppTag, then enabled protection formation checking is disabled for that sector only if the protection information application tag field has a value of 0xFFFF.
When the PI1ChkDisableMode or PI2ChkDisableMode field is set to AppRefTag, then enabled protection formation checking is disabled for that sector only if the protection information application tag field has a value of 0xFFFF and the protection information reference tag field has a value of 0xFFFF_FFFF.
The PI1ChkDisableMode or PI2ChkDisableMode field has no effect on insert operation when the inbound message request is set to insert.
The Enterprise NVMe Protection Information Processing in the following table illustrates how PI fields may be used to implement Enterprise NVMe end-to-end data type 0, 1, 2 or 3 protection information checking. Enterprise NVMe Protection Information Processing
DIF Protection
Protection Guard Check PI1/2GuardEn)
Protection Application Tag Check (PI1/2AppTagEn)
Protection Reference Tag Check (PI1/2RefTagEn)
Protection Reference Tag Mode(P1/P2RefTagMode)
Protection Check Disable (PI1/2ChkDiasbleMode)
Type 0
No
No
No
Don't care
Don't care
Type 1
Check
Check
Check
Incremental
AppTag
Type 2
Check
Check
Check
Incremental
AppTag
Type 3
Check
Check
Check
Constant
AppRefTag
The cascaded PI engines PI1 and PI2 are intended to do the following two types of system level PI processing:
PI replacement processing, where the PI field from the incoming data block is checked and striped, and a new PI field is inserted with the same or different block size.
Nested PI processing, where two PI fields with different block sizes are in the data stream as shown in the following figure.
Nested PI Layers
In both the above cases, PI2 engine cannot be configured independently, and the following rules apply.
PI2 is enabled only if PI1 is enabled.
The output data block of PI1 is always aligned to input block of PI2 at start of the blocks.
In addition, some more restrictions apply to PI2 as well, see details in the following table:
PI2 Operation Restrictions
PI1 Operation
PI2 Operation
PI2 Operation Restriction
Check and Forward
Check and Forward
Nested PI operation, single outer layer block PI for either PI1 or PI2. Otherwise, it is not valid.
Check and Strip
Nested PI operation, single outer layer block for PI2. Otherwise, it is not valid.
Insert
Nested PI operation, PI2 is outer layer PI.
Check and Strip
Check and Forward
Nested PI operation, PI1 is outer layer PI. Otherwise, it is not valid.
Check and Strip
Nested PI operation, PI1 is outer layer PI. Otherwise, it is not valid.
Insert
PI replace operation, both PI1 and PI2 are outer layer. Block size may differ.
Insert
Check and forward
Nested PI operation, single outer layer block PI for PI1. Otherwise, it is not valid.
Check and Strip
Not valid
Insert
Nested PI operation, P2 is outer layer PI. Otherwise, it it is not valid.
PI operation may trigger a separate early PI completion in addition to ingress DPS completion. The early PI completion is triggered by PI1 or PI2 after PI operation completes, while normal ingress DPS completion is triggered after all operations gets completed. Early PI completion is only triggered for data flows where PI1 or PI2 are not the last operation. The early PI completion is enabled per inbound message request by PICplMsgEn. The early PI completion has the format as the normal ingress DPS completion with CplTyp set to 1 (PI).
